title: minister launches welsh governments clean air plan wales improve air quality
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityPoor air quality is the biggest environmental risk to public health and also has effects on permit bioersity and the natural environment.In Wales, poor air quality contributes to a reduced le expectancy equivalent to between , and , deaths each year ndash often having a pronounced impact on the most vulnerable, such as the very young or very old, and those with respiratory and cardiovascular conditions.The Clean Air Plan identies a range of actions to be delivered by the Welsh Government and our partners to improving the nationrsquos air quality.The measures outlined in the Plan will work alongside existing schemes to reduce public exposure to air pollution.These actions will reduce air pollution, health risks and inequalities in order to improve public health.They will also support our natural environment through actions supporting bioersity and Welsh agriculture, reducing emissions from industry and creating sustainable places to live in, which will improve our quality of le.MORE STORIESConsultation launched on plans to reduce single use plastics in WalesApplication to change Barry waste wood facility permit withdrawnIncinerator protest at Senedd follows in wake of Barry biomass beginning its commissioning phaseThe Plan links strategies and initiatives which encourage more people to walk, cycle, or use public transport complementing the Active Travel Act and the Welsh Governmentrsquos Transforming Towns Initiative.Some of the measures include signicant investment in active travel infrastructure, improving rail services and supporting decarbonisation through our aim for a zero tailpipe exhaust emission taxi and bus fleet by  and investigating measures to support a reduction in personal vehicle use such as road user charging, Clean Air Zones and or Low Emission Zones.The Plan also includes implementing the electric vehicle charging strategy and supporting an increase in the proportion of vehicles which are ultra-low emissionand promoting a sht to ULEVs for waste collection. reviewing the powers local authorities have to tackle emissions from domestic burning investigating the contribution bonfires and fireworks make to levels of harmful emissions and increasing air quality monitoring through the development of a new Air Pollution Monitoring Network to protect the public, especially those most vulnerable, from air pollution.It involves intelligent tree and hedge planting alongside expanding woodlands to support air quality improvements strengthening the control of emissions in agriculture delivering enhanced behaviour change communications and producing new statutory guidance to help protect workforces from exposure to air pollution and proposals for a new Clean Air Act for Wales to enhance existing legislation and introduce new powers to further tackle air pollution.Minister for environment, energy and rural affairs, Lesley Grfiths said: ldquoI am very pleased to announce the launch of our Clean Air Plan, which sets out how we will look to improve air quality across Wales, and deal with those problems caused by air pollution, during the next  years.ldquoThe aims outlined in the Plan are there to safeguard the most vulnerable, but improving our air quality nationwide will be to the benefit of everyone in Wales, and itrsquos something we should all want and strive for. But in order to achieve that, we have to take action now.ldquoMuch of that work is already underway ndash despite the recent pandemic, we have been able to support local authorities in commencing work on schemes to improve air quality across Wales.ldquoWe know that as people across Wales have responded to those restrictions imposed due to the covid- pandemic, they have changed how they do things and taken on new habits ndash including decreasing their reliance on cars, and doing more in their local areas, rather than feeling the need to travel long distances.She added: ldquoWhile the work outlined in the plan will run across government, the measures involved cannot be achieved by government alone ndash well have a role to play in ensuring that we tackle the problems of air pollution and poor air quality.ldquoWhile the Clean Air Plan will require us all to play our part in tackling poor air quality, the recent actions undertaken by the people of Wales show what we can do when we come together in order to protect the most vulnerable, and to respond to those problems which face all of us.Healthy Air Cymru chairman, Joseph Carter said: ldquoHaving been involved in the development of this plan, we are incredibly proud of what it has become."This ambitious proposal offers the opportunity to transform our country and create a greener, healthier Wales.ldquoHowever, this plan cannot be delivered overnight and will need support from everyone across Wales."Now is the time to make this issue a priority ndash this is about delivering for people and communities across Wales.ldquoWe all have a role to play in improving air quality across Wales, and through working together, we can build upon it and work together to deliver for future generations."Letrsquos make  the fresh start Wales needs, by passing this ambitious plan through a robust Clean Air Act.An earlier version of the Plan went out for public consultation in December the revised Plan in its present form follows that consultation, which lasted for  weeks.The consultation included events with stakeholders and engagement events with young people. article_url   content_id   site_id title: vaughan gething visits penarth club recognise lockdown efforts
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityMr Gething, whose son regularly attended football training in the junior section at the football club tied to the social club prior to the pandemic, stopped by to talk about the challenges that will face the club in the near future as a result of Covid-, and members explained how they have used the closure to make an even better go of le after lockdown.Dean Ford, a committee member at the club, who initially contacted Mr Gething to help mark the reopening, spoke about le during lockdown, and the challenges ahead.ldquoItrsquos been a really dficult and worrying time, and there is little doubt wersquod have closed without the support of the business grant we received, he said.The social clubis home to more than  junior footballers alone, making it the biggest footballing institution in the Vale.Dean Ford and Lee WilliamsIt is also now home to the only pub in Cogan, following the closure of The Station during lockdown.Close friends with tenants Natasha and Gareth, Mr Fordand fellow committee member Lee Williams said it compounded their concerns for the industry.ldquoItrsquos a real shame because theyrsquore great people and we were always in there, Mr Ford said. ldquoItrsquos a worrying time for pubs, but wersquove got through the worst of it hopefully, thanks I think to how cautious the Welsh Government has been."Over the past ten weeks, a group of eight volunteers have teamed up to refurbish the social club ready for Monday and beyond.The club was busy on Monday after the club asked for support on social medialdquoWe had no beer garden and all our events were cancelled, so we really would have been closed for good without the grant we received, said Mr Williams.ldquoThe only people that have been in here since March are the maintenance guys, and theyrsquove done a great job. Wersquove also really tried to push the reopening on social media and it seems to have worked.A few new faces were in on Monday afternoon, while some older friends ed to support the club too.ldquoItrsquos brilliant to see and is something we really need at the moment, Mr Williams added.Vaughan Gething speaking with membersAs a trial, the club will be opening from pm Monday to Thursday, and will continue operating from pm on Fridays and weekends.On Vaughan Gething visiting the club, Mr Ford added: ldquoItrsquos nice to have the recognition and for him to recognise wersquove suffered. Itrsquos so important for the message to support local businesses.On the challenges of social distancing and avoiding new cases after lockdown, Mr Ford said: ldquoItrsquos dficult but wersquove done everything we can in terms of people signing in, not standing at the bar, wersquove implemented a one-way system.       ,params: .pushldquoHopefully things will get a bit more relaxed soon. It feels like Wales is in the best place to start doing that.Mr Gething said it had been ldquoreally dficult to see the club struggle and praised them for their resilience.ldquoThe refurb here is fantastic and I felt it was so important to come here and recognise the work that has been put in, he said.ldquoFor the sake of clubs like this, it is so important people follow the guidance to avoid a repeat of lockdown, which could be really dficult for businesses to respond to.ldquoI appreciate itrsquos dficult because these are social environments, but I would urge caution ndash especially come the autumn and winter when we expect new cases may occur.ldquoIrsquom confident the test and trace process will improve and work to mitigate those concerns, and ensure we donrsquot see what wersquore now seeing in places like Australia and Spain. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log        ,params: .push-- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a commentOrder byOldest firstNewest firstHighest scoredLowest scoredLoading comments... story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityAs reported in the Penarth Times on Thursday, the town councilsaid the results show ldquowidespread backing for changes.The survey, which attracted  responses, showed  per cent of people thought there should be more outdoor space for pedestrians and businesses.Seventy-five per cent thought parking arrangements needed to change, and  per cent said the town needs to ldquoprepare for the future.Some traders, who oppose the changes ndash specically a one-way traffic system around the town and making Windsor Road and Lower Glebe Street a traffic free zone, have said the questions in the survey were too generalised and misleading.As a result of the survey, Penarth Town Council have proposed the following changes to the original ideas:Windsor Road from Arcot Street to the roundabout as a ldquoshared space for delivery vehicles and buses, with a mph speed limit.Lower Glebe Street as a ldquoshared space for delivery vehicles and disabled bays. Other vehicles should not use Lower Glebe Street as a through road.Bus stops will remain as they are. There were concerns over the impact of a bus stop on Hickman Road for traders, due to air pollution, noise pollution and congestion.A two-way system to remain on Stanwell Road from the library to the traffic lights, to allow easy access to the bus stop on Rectory Road and to prevent congestion and ldquorat running through Hickman Road and Arcot Street. A two-way system to also remain from Windsor Road to Railway Terrace.The number of parking bays has also changed. There will now be  extra bays proposed, with  of them on Plassey Street.The leader of the town council, Cllr Rhiannon Birch, explained the findings and what happens next.ldquoEven before Covid-, town centres across the country were facing issues, including the need to modernise infrastructure, and the impact of online shopping, she said. ldquoThe current pandemic has added to the scale of the challenge.ldquoThe consultation shows that a clear majority recognise the need for a degree of change in the town centre, both for it to survive in the present and to thrive in future.ldquoThe results call for the establishment of a greater degree of safe space and proposals which increase a degree of pedestrianisation whilst also increasing parking spaces.ldquoThe results show substantial agreement on these aims. Reflecting this widespread and clear response, Penarth Town Council calls on our partners in the Vale of Glamorgan Council to embrace the results and recommendations.ldquoSpecically, Penarth Town Council believes that creating a safer environment through the closure of Windsor Road to traffic for part of the day, between Arcot Street and the roundabout, including the Lower Glebe Street, would be the best way to ensure that people can feel confident about shopping safely. It would allow safe use of the space in front of shops, bars, cafes and restaurants.ldquoIt also lessens the need for one-way systems on pavements for pedestrians, which are perplexing for many and hard to implement. title: vale glamorgan library buildings reopen controlled basis
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityLibrary services were initially suspended in an effort to tackle the coronavirus before a click-and-collect service was launched in late June.That allows members to borrow books, audiobooks and DVDs on an appointment basis and even submit preference requests relating to authors or genres.Now residents will be able to access further facilities as the use of PCs and the physical browsing of books is permitted again.Initially, PCs can be booked for a -minute period once a week, with the number available reduced to allow for appropriate social distancing.Fixed time limits will also mean staff can properly sanitise machines between uses.MORE STORIESVale of Glamorgan libraries offer click and collect serviceBarry library closes in wake of coronavirus concernsVale Libraries lockdown Lit Facebook group established for book-loversIt will also be possible to secure a -minute slot to browse and select books from the libraries, with strict restrictions on the number of people admitted to the buildings at any one time.Library members can make appointments for either of these services by phone.Vale council cabinet member for education and regeneration, Cllr Lis Burnett said: ldquoWe know what a vital role our libraries play in the lives of some of our residents, especially at a time when most are spending more time at home.ldquoReading in particular is a productive and stimulating way to fill time so Irsquom delighted that we are now able to make more of our library services available again.ldquoWhile increasing numbers of people have been accessing books, resources and activities online, for many the reopening of library buildings will be very welcomelsquoOur library staff have worked hard to provide as many facilities as possible online, but I know they are looking forward to seeing familiar faces and hopefully some new ones too.ldquoResidents will be able to use PCs and visit libraries in person to browse books though both activities will be tightly controlled.ldquoSafety remains the number one priority and all appropriate measures will be in place to protect both library members and staff.During this period, chairs will be removed from the libraries to discourage sitting, toilets will be closed to the public and there will be no meetings, activities or room bookings available.Anyone entering the building will be asked to use hand gel and complete a track and trace card giving their name and contact details.Library staff will work behind protective screens when at a desk and wear visors at other times and all books will be quarantined for  hours before being cleaned and put back into circulation.Current weekday opening times will remain the same initially, with Barry and Cowbridge operating from am to pm and pm to pm, and Llantwit Major open for the second of those periods.The Libraries will also open between am and pm on Saturdays.As building improvement work is shortly due to take place at Penarth Library, that will not open in the same way as the councilrsquos other libraries.However, it will continue to offer a phone and internet click-and-collect service, as will Barry, Cowbridge and Llantwit Major.Community libraries in Rhoose, St Athan and Sully are also offering a click-and-collect service, with Dinas Powys and Wenvoe likely to join them in the near future.Some other council services will also be available face to face at the Civic Offices on an appointment basis from Monday, August .Appointments can now be made for registrars, council tax and benefits services by telephone.More details can be found at www.valeofglamorgan.gov.ukGet involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and title: albert road trinity churches merge penarth methodist church

check at Albert Road uncovered huge issues with the structure of the church, dating back to damage suffered in the Second World War.A congregation at Albert Road, which has dwindled over the last few years, would not have been able to raise the pound, required.Now, in what was one of Reverend Phyl Fanningrsquos last acts before he moves closer to his family near Liverpool, the two churches will merge and become Penarth Methodist Church.Rev Fanning, who has been widely praised for ldquobringing the churches into the st century, using social media and installing screens in the church so people can watch at home, says the new changes signal the start of a new positive beginning.Musical director Janet Pedwell said: ldquoThis is not a negative thing, and will be a seamless transition, as the two congregations have been holding services together for a while now.ldquoIt will make one bigger and stronger congregation, which made much more sense for us than trying to get the cash for the repairs.Services will still be delivered at the newly renamed church, which was Trinity, at Stanwell Road.ldquoWe want it to be even more of a community church for everyone, Mrs Pedwell added. title: a level students advised look clearing last minute grading changes
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityProfessor Julia Buckingham, president of Universities UK, told students receiving their results on Thursday not to panicthey miss out on the grades for their offer at university.She said that universities will be as flexible as they can in the ldquounusual circumstances and that students should look at the courses available in clearing.An analysis by the PA news agency shows that there were nearly , undergraduate courses across the UK and Northern Ireland listed with clearing vacancies.These include nearly , courses at the elite Russell Group universities, according to the admissions service Ucasrsquos clearing website on Wednesday.Prof Buckingham said: ldquoOn the eve of A-level results, our advice to students is to carry on as planned, which meansyou miss out on the grades for your offer donrsquot panic.ldquoSpeak to your teachers for their advice and get in touch with your first-choice university as soon as possible ndash universities will be as flexible as they can in these unusual circumstances ndash and look at the courses available through clearing.Her comments come after ministers denied that the exam system in England had been thrown into ldquoconfusion following th-hour changes to the way A-level and GCSE results will be assessed.Education Secretary Gavin Williamson announced late on Tuesday that students will be able to use their results in mock tests to appealthey are unhappy with the grades they are given.The move came less than  hours before students receive their calculated A-level results following the cancellation of actual exams amid the Covid- crisis. vw,vw,px, px"Gavin Williamson has said students in England can use their mock results as the basis for appeals Clearing has become an increasingly popular route to securing a university place in recent years, in part due to reforms that lted the cap on the number of students universities could recruit.It is also used by students who may have changed their mind about their course or university and want to find somewhere new, or those who have done better than expected and want to trade places.An analysis, conducted by PA, shows that as of Wednesday morning, for applicants living in England there were , courses with availability across  UK universities and colleges.Of the  Russell Group universities, nearly three in fourhave at least one course advertised on the clearing site, with , courses potentially available.Ucas chief executive Clare Marchant told PA on Monday that as many as , applicants could find a place via clearing, up from , last year, despite fears about the impact of Covid- on the student experience.ldquoI think we will end up with signicant numbers through clearing, Ms Marchant said.ldquoI think itrsquos going to be probably the busiest yet.Anja Hazebroek, director of student recruitment and marketing at the University of Hull, said that the impact of cancelling exams on clearing was not known.But she said that due to Covid- and the virusrsquos impact on the job market, there might be more prospective students wanting to study closer to home or go to university when they had previously decided not to.She added: ldquoWe may have more or less students looking for clearing places, but we are well prepared to help give support and advice to all prospective students.ldquoWith Covid impacting the job market, as well as changing peoplersquos personal priorities ndash such as wanting to study on a single-site campus university to avoid the need for public transport ndash we may see more movement than usual as people choose to go to universities closer to home or decide to go to university after previously planning not title: autumn date set opening new south lake leisure centre
story: Restaurant which provides employment for young people with special needs closes its doorsTraffic disruption expected as two £k NI road schemes to startNewsTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthPeopleRead ThisCoronavirusSportFootballOther SportWhats OnArts and EntertainmentThings To DoLestyleCarsHomes and GardensNewsPeopleAutumn date set for opening of new South Lake Leisure CentreA date has been set for the opening of the new south lake leisure centre in Craigavon with the multi-million-pound facility to open its doors on November .By The NewsroomTuesday, th July , : pmUpdated Tuesday, th July , : pm""The largest capital project to date undertaken by ABC Council, and among the largest in Northern Ireland, the new multi-use sports and leisure complex is described by the council as a major new flagship health and wellbeing destination.Work on the facility was halted by the coronavirus outbreak. Since ing to site Farrans, the contractor in charge of the build, has ensured the contract is completed ready for opening in the Autumn.Farrans has been spearheading the build since initial enabling works got under way early in , creating  jobs on site during construction as part of a project which has delivered at least £. million in direct wages to the local economy.Located at the south side of Craigavon’s balancing lake, the facility is a landmark venue for the area and is situated within a pre-existing network of walking and cycling paths covering around three miles. The council hopes the new leisure centre will welcome visitors from across the borough and beyond to its new -metre pool, a young children’s indoor leisure water feature, a ,m state-of-the-art gym, multiple studios, health and wellbeing suite, sensory room, eight-court sports halls, spin studio, soft play area and an on-site café.It also incorporates an outdoor water sports provision offering a wide range of water based activities including windsurfing, water skiing and paddle sports. The council says the scale of South Lake Leisure Centre has been future-proofed to meet the needs of a growing population and a raising demand from a range of leisure, amateur and professional sporting enthusiasts.Lord Mayor of Armagh City, Banbridge and Craigavon, Councillor Kevin Savage, sai: “With a confirmed opening date just  weeks away, I am delighted that this stunning new centre - which will have fabulous facilities for everyone in the borough to access and enjoy - is almost complete.“South Lake Leisure Centre provides a once-in-a-generation opportunity to transform and dramatically enhance the quality of health and leisure provision within the borough, providing community access for everyone to the best facilities available in the UK and Ireland.”As part of the preparations for the official opening of South Lake Leisure Centre, interim arrangements have been agreed for leisure facilities in Portadownand Brownlow . Cascades Leisure Complex will be open to the public for lane swimming only in August, remaining open until Saturday th October.Craigavon Leisure Centre will remain open to the public for gym only until Monday th October. Waves Leisure Complex will be closed to the public.When all these facilities, which are approaching the end of their al le close, leisure staff will begin their training at the new South Lake Leisure Centre building.""Most Popular." data-index"" data-s-event"gaEvent" data-s-ec"navigation" data-s-ea"most popular" data-s-el"" title"" class"sc-drMfKT fpqScQ"" alt"" layout"fill"" data-index"" data-s-event"gaEvent" data-s-ec"navigation" data-s-ea"most popular" title"" data-s-el"" class"sc-bGbJRg eOOfIS"Most Popular." data-index"" data-s-event"gaEvent" data-s-ec"navigation" data-s-ea"most popular" data-s-el"" title"" class"sc-drMfKT fpqScQ"" alt"" layout"fill"" data-index"" data-s-event"gaEvent" data-s-ec"navigation" data-s-ea"most popular" title"" data-s-el"" class"sc-bGbJRg eOOfIS"This website and its associated newspaper are members of Independent Press Standards Organisation Follow us onExploreNewsSportWhats OnLestyleMore from Portadown TimesAnnouncementsJobsPublic NoticesMust ReadBuy a PhotoDirectoryLocal GuideReader ShopUseful LinksContact UsAdvertise My BusinessAdvertise a JobPlace your AdSubscribeEventsArchiveReaders Charter" fill"#ea"©JPIMedia Publishing Ltd. ." target"_self" href"#" id"cookieSettings" class"sc-gxMtzJ sc-dfVpRl dLpuYr"Cookie SettingsTerms and ConditionsPrivacy policyNews you can trust since News" class"expand" role"button" tabindex""""" scale translate " points"  .  . Norman lived directly opposite the bridge and could often be seen sitting on it. INPT-.Speaking during August’s meeting of Council’s economic development and regeneration committee discussion turned to the environmental improvements being carried out at Woodhouse Street in Portadown.When completed, the works will ensure environmental improvements to the pedestrian and vehicular tunnel under the Northway and ensure improvements to wayfinding and landscaping in the area.However, speaking about the current state of affairs at Woodhouse Street, Councillor Paul Duffy claimed the contractor had “left a bit of a mess” when the street was dug up.“The contractor left an awful lot of stones laying about, could Council ensure it is cleaned up  Can someone go down and have a word with the contractor  I have tried to myself but have had no success.”Upon hearing this, title: kelly pays tribute john humes vision
